messageBody:
Hello amd64_hacker,

Sending my answer to your e-mail address was unintentional. I was away from
home for New Year and I used a webmail site. Commonly I use Outlook Express
with OE-QuoteFix to download my messages and send my replies.

It's rather true that QuickScript's use in English is its only relation with
the Latin alphabet. But I think the use of the same arrangement of dots for
letters with similar sounds has a mnemonic value we should take into
consideration. More similarities of shape between voiced and unvoiced
consonants are less apparent in QS than in Shavian. So why should they be
marked in a braille code for QS?
The languages which use a completely different system are only Japanese,
whose braille code is based on the kana syllabaries, each base syllable
being represented by a single braille cell (the three dots in the upper left
corner are used for the vowel, the three dots in the lower right corner are
used for the consonant, therefore the Japanese braille system is more an
abugida than a true syllabary) and Korean which uses different but closely
related combinations of dots for its initial and final consonants.
I were told that Tibetan also uses a very different system, but I haven't
seen it yet.

I'm not yet really litterate in braille, I'm only learning to read it by
touch in French (I'm not visually impaired). But I think there aren't
characters fundamentally easier to read than others. The only thing to
remember is that characters such as '⠓' dots 1-2-5 and '⠦' dots 2-3-6
(characters with the same shape but not at the same place in the cell)
cannot be easily distinguished when they're used alone. Therefore it's
common practice to only use, for the letters of an alphabet, braille cells
which have a raised dot in the upper row and one, possibly the same, in the
left column. There are 44 such combinations on a total of 63 possible
combinations in 6-dot braille, and 184 on a total of 255 possible
combinations in 8-dot braille. Since there are 44 letters in QS, 6-dot
braille would be enough, the more so as many devices, such as Perkins
typewriters, allows only the 6-dot braille.
But it wouldn't be useless to specify also the combinations used for
punctuation marks, digits and all the other symbols since those may change
from language to language.

I'm thinking of one or two Quikscript Braille (QS/B) mappings and I'll share
them with the group ASAP.

Happy new year to everybody.

JF

> Hi,
>
> Thanks for your reply, I think you may have sent your message to my
> address rather than the group address.
> I'm replying to you directly rather than posting to the group in case
> this was intentional.
> Please feel free to quote this message on the group if you wish. :)
>
> I agree with you on the computer terminal point, that was the kind of
> thing I was thinking about when I mentioned the writing/printing kit
> being already available.
>
> I'm actually more in favour of the second approach for the same
> reasons you are in favour of the first. :)
> Quikscript is only somewhat related to the Latin alphabet and then
> only because the Latin alphabet is somewhat related to the English
> language.
> I think that it would be better to create a mapping with the most
> frequently occurring characters assigned to the easiest to recognise
> shapes, with an eye to keeping shapes as dissimilar as possible.
>
> However I'm not interested in working on the Quikscript Braille
> mapping because I'm well aware that I'm not even nearly qualified to
> do so.
> I'm not blind, I don't know any blind people and I can't read or write
> Braille, I have no idea what the criteria for a good mapping might be.
> My thoughts on the Braille mapping are simply what seem to be common
> sense to me.
>
> Why not create a Quikscript Braille (QS/B?) mapping and share it with
> the group?
> That would get the ball rolling and hopefully get some real feedback
> on what's right/wrong.
>
> bn130627@... wrote:
>> Hello.
>>
>> Be it too confining or not, braille is by far the widest way to read
>> and write among the visually impaired people and surely the easiest
>> tactile script to implement in a computer terminal.
>> There are basically two ways to adapt braille to a new language
>> and/or script:
>> 1. Use the already known Latin braille alphabet and assign your new
>> letters to Latin letters with a similar value or shape. That's the
>> way chosen for most script (Russian, Greek, Arabic, Hebrew, Mandarin
>> Chinese, Cantonese...). E.g. in Greek they use the dots 1-2-4-5 for
>> the letter gamma, as the Latin letter 'g', although gamma is the 3rd
>> letter of the Greek alphabet.
>> 2. Don't consider the Latin braille and adapt it to your language,
>> like Japanese, Korean and Tibetan.
>>
>> Since QS is somewhat related to the Latin alphabet, I think the 1st
>> approach would be better.
>>
>> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>>
>> Fair enough.I think the only 'real' answer could come from a blind
>> person anyway.I think the main advantage that Braille has is that the
>> kit forwriting/printing it is already available to those who need
>> it.Terry Smithwick wrote:>> If you look at the 'cheat sheets' for
>> ThumbScript,> you'll see the written representation. The>
>> 'characters' are ambiguous unless you show the dot> locations as
>> well as the strokes; and even worse, most> of the characters can be
>> reverse-stroked, for numbers> and symbols.>> I only made the
>> ThumbScript and Moon Symbol> suggestions to stimulate thinking
>> outside the 2x3> Braille box, which I believe to be too confining.>>
